messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: idebug65 [mailto:idebug@...]
> ...
> >
> > a) Organize test cases in the same package as the class under test
> > b) Change the accessibility of the class under test
> >
> > ------------------
> But a and b are the things that I don't want to do, if you read my
> original message. There are many reasons why I need it in a
> different directory.

But do consider compromising on restricted access.
I personally hate final classes, such as String. probably good reasons for
it but...
(You are most likely to be the one that will feel the restrictions, not
being able to extend it)
You could refine the way you restrict your class (modifier on constructor
default/protected/private)
making individual methods final etc... and not make your class final.
If you make your class not final and the constructor(s) default you could
make a subclass in the same package (but test tree) and use that instance in
your testcase that resides wherever you want it to.
If you really, really want to, check the class name in the constructor to be
one of those two, throw an exception otherwise.
But I still think it is a lot of effort, and it does not make code better
understandable...

> Also to change the production code just to
> satisfy unit testing doesn't sound so good. There is a reason why we
> didn't want to make it public. So do you know of any graceful way of
> doing this besides a and b?
>
>
